moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Bc5 6. c3 b5 7. Bc2 d6 8. d4 Bb6 9. a4
comment: White probes the queen-side and wonders how Black will defend Pb5, now that Ra8-b8 isn't available.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Bc5 6. c3 b5 7. Bc2 d6 8. d4 Bb6 9. a4 Bg4 10. axb5 axb5 11. Rxa8 Qxa8 12. h3 Bh5
comment: This is bound to get Black into trouble. What's wrong with the simple exchanges?

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Bc5 6. c3 b5 7. Bc2 d6 8. d4 Bb6 9. a4 Bg4 10. axb5 axb5 11. Rxa8 Qxa8 12. h3 Bh5 13. d5 Na7
comment: Now Black's pieces are on the perimeter. It's only ...c7-c6 which gives him a chance to counter against White's center. White might bolster Pd5 with b2-b3 and c3-c4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Bc5 6. c3 b5 7. Bc2 d6 8. d4 Bb6 9. a4 Bg4 10. axb5 axb5 11. Rxa8 Qxa8 12. h3 Bh5 13. d5 Na7 14. Na3 c6 15. Bg5 Bd8 16. dxc6 Qxc6 17. Bxf6 Bxf3 18. Qxf3 Bxf6 19. Bb3 O-O
comment: White's preference for piece play carried a little more risk, but if done well a bigger payoff. Bc1-g5xf6 was a threat to Black's king. At this point Black has defended and (surprisingly) the position looks somewhat like a Sicilian Defense, Sveshnikov Variation. White's play on the d-file can't really pay off (winning Pd6 is very difficult) , but using d5 and the a-file can provide a way to play where Bf6 can't defend!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Bc5 6. c3 b5 7. Bc2 d6 8. d4 Bb6 9. a4 Bg4 10. axb5 axb5 11. Rxa8 Qxa8 12. h3 Bh5 13. d5 Na7 14. Na3 c6 15. Bg5 Bd8 16. dxc6 Qxc6 17. Bxf6 Bxf3 18. Qxf3 Bxf6 19. Bb3 O-O 20. Nc2 Nc8 21. Nb4 Qb7 22. Ra1 Bd8 23. Bd5 Qc7 24. Nc6
comment: White blocks Black's pieces maximally and threatens invasion at a7 or a8. This is terrific play and there's little Black can do to prevent it.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Bc5 6. c3 b5 7. Bc2 d6 8. d4 Bb6 9. a4 Bg4 10. axb5 axb5 11. Rxa8 Qxa8 12. h3 Bh5 13. d5 Na7 14. Na3 c6 15. Bg5 Bd8 16. dxc6 Qxc6 17. Bxf6 Bxf3 18. Qxf3 Bxf6 19. Bb3 O-O 20. Nc2 Nc8 21. Nb4 Qb7 22. Ra1 Bd8 23. Bd5 Qc7 24. Nc6 Kh8 25. Ra8 f5

1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Bc5 6. c3 b5 7. Bc2 d6 8. d4 Bb6 9. a4 Bg4 10. axb5 axb5 11. Rxa8 Qxa8 12. h3 Bh5 13. d5 Na7 14. Na3 c6 15. Bg5 Bd8 16. dxc6 Qxc6 17. Bxf6 Bxf3 18. Qxf3 Bxf6 19. Bb3 O-O 20. Nc2 Nc8 21. Nb4 Qb7 22. Ra1 Bd8 23. Bd5 Qc7 24. Nc6 Kh8 25. Ra8 f5 26. Nxd8
comment: White chooses to just trade-off and win a pawn or two. That with the bishop v. knight advantage should give him a near-winning advantage.
